articles.title: Ephemeris
articles.summary: This document, an 'Ephemeris' from the San Jose Astronomical Association, details upcoming club activities and astronomical events for December 1982, and January and February 1983. It includes general and board meetings, various star parties at different locations, an indoor star party focused on telescope making, and highlights significant celestial events like the Geminid Meteor shower and a total lunar eclipse. The document also provides contact information for the SJAA and its bulletin editor, along with membership details.

articles.title: PRESIDENT'S COLUMN
articles.summary: This President's Column delves into the long-standing mystery behind the specific, often fractional, standard sizes of commercially available Pyrex telescope mirror blanks. The author investigates by contacting a Pyrex Product Specialist at Corning Glass Works, who clarifies historical manufacturing processes and suggests that the additional fractions were likely an overcompensation to ensure a full "clear aperture" after final trimming and finishing. The article also touches upon different Pyrex types used for various mirror sizes.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is holding its final general meeting at De Anza College on December 4th, featuring Lavis Epstein discussing relativity. Beginning in 1983, all general meetings will relocate to the University of Santa Clara's Daly Science Center, with Norm Sperling presenting on "Searching Planet Earth" using LandSat imagery at the January 22nd meeting. Norm Sperling, a former Sky & Telescope editor, also operates "Everything in the Universe," an astronomical service.

articles.title: November Board Meeting.
articles.summary: The November Board Meeting discussed soliciting member suggestions for future lecture topics and nominees for the 1983 G. Bruce Blair Award. A major point of discussion centered on establishing a club observing site and permanent telescope, prompted by Wayne Rosing's offer to donate a 40" telescope blank once the club secures tax-exempt status. The Board is seeking member input on acquiring a dark-sky site, designing the observatory, building the telescope, and fundraising for this ambitious project.

articles.title: January's Bulletin.
articles.summary: The January Bulletin editor will be absent for the last two weeks of December and requests all contributors to submit their material directly to Denni. Denni will be responsible for compiling the January Bulletin during the editor's absence.

articles.title: Andrew Fraknoi Joins KGO-FM Radio.
articles.summary: Andrew Fraknoi has joined ABC's KGO-FM Radio to host "Exploring the Universe," a new science talk show airing Sundays. This program marks the Bay Area's first regularly scheduled commercial science broadcast, aiming to make modern science accessible through discussions with scientists, news, and public event listings. Fraknoi is a professor of astronomy and physics at San Francisco State University and the executive officer of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.

articles.title: MAN-MADE SHADOW BANDS?
articles.summary: Don Machholz describes a phenomenon he's observed for six years: brilliant landing lights from distant airplanes casting moving, triangular, or irregular light patterns onto surfaces. He compares these patterns to natural shadow bands seen during solar eclipses, which are caused by atmospheric air cells. Machholz asks readers if they have witnessed similar "man-made shadow bands" or have theories regarding their cause.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY AT INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: This article addresses concerns about a perceived lack of astronomy activities at indoor club meetings, suggesting various projects such as observational classes, drive corrector assembly, and mirror-making. The author encourages greater member participation to overcome the perception of a club 'clique,' emphasizing that involvement is key to engagement. It also highlights several ongoing member projects, including mirror grinding, comet seeking, and occultation timing, while inviting readers to share their own projects or viewpoints.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: The article provides an update on cometary activity at the close of 1982, noting visible periodic comets, Comet Austin's fading, and the recovery of a well-known periodic comet. It then delves into historical observations by Charles Messier, detailing how he discovered numerous Messier objects (e.g., M1, M50-M52, M56-M60) while primarily observing or searching for comets, and highlights instances of mistaken identity between comets and deep-sky objects by various observers.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: Halley's Comet (1982i) was successfully recovered on October 16th by a team at Mt. Palomar using the 200-inch telescope, confirming its position very close to D. Yeomans' prediction. The recovery was independently confirmed two days later by astronomers at Kitt Peak. The comet, estimated to have a 1.4 km radius nucleus, is expected to reach perihelion on February 9.3, 1986, and become visible in smaller telescopes by early September 1985.

articles.title: Periodic Comet D'Arrest (1982e)
articles.summary: The article provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet D'Arrest (1982e) from late November to early January, including its Right Ascension, Declination, and predicted visual magnitude. It notes that the comet is rapidly fading and moving further away from both Earth and the Sun, indicating that optimal observing time is quickly diminishing. The data is adapted from MPC 6535.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko (1982f)
articles.summary: This article provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko (1982f) from late November to early January, detailing its celestial coordinates and magnitude. It notes the comet's close approach to Earth (0.4 AU), suggests it might appear one magnitude fainter than published, and describes it as a small, roughly 1 arcminute object that would be nearly overhead in December.

articles.title: Great Comets: Notes on Reporting a Comet Discovery
articles.summary: This article provides detailed instructions on how to report a new comet discovery to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO) via telegram, including specific information to send like object type, position, magnitude, and appearance. It also advises discoverers to confirm their findings, noting that many initial reports are invalid, and suggests follow-up communication by letter. The piece concludes by mentioning the continuation of a comet-related series in the publication.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor
articles.summary: Gerald W. Rattley writes to Steve, inquiring about his November bulletin, which he has not received by November 15th, and provides an update on his new permanent address. Steve responds, explaining that the bulk mailings, including the bulletin, were severely delayed due to an overwhelming volume of election-related material prioritized by federal law, causing significant backlogs for the postal service.

articles.title: Space Program Update
articles.summary: This 'Space Program Update' details recent activities including the Space Shuttle Columbia's successful launch of its first commercial payloads and the preparation of Challenger for its maiden mission, STS-6, which is experiencing delays. It also covers international developments like the Soviet Union's new navigation system and a space endurance record, ongoing issues with the Ariane rocket, and discussions around a potential fifth Shuttle orbiter and a space nuclear power source dispute. Furthermore, the article touches on plans for a large Soviet rocket, the development of the Lassocraft platform, and approval for Shuttle launches from Vandenberg AFB.

articles.title: EXPLORING THE UNIVERSE SEMINARS
articles.summary: Bill Dellinges recounts his experience assisting Dr. William Kaufmann's "Exploring the Universe" seminars, providing additional observing time with his C-14 telescope and teaching basic sky navigation. He notes participants' interest in learning constellations over deep celestial mechanics. Dellinges has been invited back for six sessions next summer, providing dates, tuition, and contact information for prospective attendees.

articles.title: THE STAR OF BETHLEHEM
articles.summary: This article analyzes a series of unique planetary conjunctions and movements between August 3 BCE and December 2 BCE, suggesting they could explain the biblical 'Star of Bethlehem.' The author proposes that these astronomical phenomena, particularly involving Jupiter's interactions with Venus, Mars, and Regulus in the constellation Leo, align with ancient astrological interpretations predicting the birth of a king and specific biblical prophecies about the Christ Child. The text argues that these rare occurrences would have greatly excited observers like the Magi, leading them to Jerusalem and Bethlehem.

articles.title: Ads
articles.summary: This document contains several classified advertisements for astronomy-related items. Listings include a Celestron 2" Star Diagonal, a vintage refractor box, 55-gallon steel drums for mirror grinding, and brass gear stock suitable for telescope drives.

articles.title: A THRILLING, CHILLING AUTUMN STAR PARTY
articles.summary: This article recounts a "chilling, thrilling" autumn star party at Fremont Peak on November 17th, where despite cold conditions and low attendance, the author and a companion experienced an exceptionally rewarding night. Key observations included splitting double stars like Rigel and Trapezium, numerous Messier and NGC objects, and first-time visual sightings of the Horsehead Nebula and Rosette Nebula, aided by excellent seeing conditions later in the evening. The report emphasizes the value of persistence, proper preparation, and specific observing techniques for challenging deep-sky targets.

articles.title: NEWS MATERIAL
articles.summary: This document is an internal "SIAA Bulletin" from the San Jose Astronomical Association, explicitly labeled as "NEWS MATERIAL." It contains the association's address and a postal marking dated October 7, 1982, indicating its historical context and origin as a club publication.

articles.title: STAR MEETING & STAR PARTY SITES
articles.summary: This document features a hand-drawn map detailing various locations designated for star meetings and star parties. The map includes roads, landmarks, and names of these sites, which appear to be concentrated around the San Jose area, serving as specific astronomical observation locations.
